question.text: Ammonia forms the complex ion  <math> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mtext>Cu</mtext><msub> <mrow> <mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msub> <mrow> <mtext>NH</mtext> </mrow> <mtext>3</mtext> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">)</mo> </mrow> <mtext>4</mtext> </msub> <mo stretchy="false">]</mo> </mrow> <mrow> <mtext>2</mtext><mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </math>  with copper ions in alkaline solution but not in acidic solution. The probable reason for this is

options.text: In acidic solution, hydration protects  <math> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>Cu</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mtext>2</mtext><mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </math> ions

In acidic solution, proton co-ordinates with ammonia molecules to form  <math> <mrow> <msup> <mrow> <mtext>NH</mtext> </mrow> <mrow> <mtext>4</mtext><mo>+</mo> </mrow> </msup> </mrow> </math>  ions and  <math> <mrow> <msub> <mrow> <mtext>NH</mtext> </mrow> <mtext>3</mtext> </msub> </mrow> </math> molecules are not available

In alkaline solutions insoluble  <math>  <mrow>   <mtext>Cu</mtext><msub>    <mrow>     <mrow><mo>(</mo>      <mrow>       <mtext>OH</mtext>      </mrow>     <mo>)</mo></mrow>    </mrow>    <mtext>2</mtext>   </msub>     </mrow> </math>   is precipitated which is soluble in excess of any alkali

solution.text:
Cu2+(aq)+NH3(l)+H+(aq)→NH4+(aq)+Cu2+(aq)

In acidic solution proton coordinates with ammonia molecules to form   NH 4 +  does not have a lone pair and hence cannot form co-ordination compounds.

Whereas in alkaline solution   NH 3  molecules are free to form the complex.
